conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the shape of the object and the angle of the light source.
The length of the shadow is inversely proportional to the height of the light source above the object. The closer the light source is to the object, the longer the shadow.
In the image, the light source is positioned above and slightly behind the objects, casting shadows that extend forward from the objects.

premise: When the light source moves forward, it will be positioned more directly above the objects.
conclusion: This change in position will affect the length and direction of the shadows.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadows will become shorter because the light rays will be more perpendicular to the ground.
conclusion: The direction of the shadows will also change. Instead of extending forward, they will now extend more directly downward or slightly backward, depending on the exact position of the light source.

premise: Shadow A (Glove): The shadow will become shorter and will extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
conclusion: Shadow A will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.

premise: Shadow B (Typewriter): Similar to Shadow A, it will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
conclusion: Shadow B will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.

premise: Shadow C (Bird): This shadow will also become shorter and will extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
conclusion: Shadow C will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.

premise: Shadow D (Peaches): The shadow will become shorter and will extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
conclusion: Shadow D will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.

premise: When the light source moves forward, above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will become shorter and will extend more directly downward or slightly backward, depending on the exact position of the light source.
conclusion: The A, B, C and D shift backward, moving beneath the objects, and become shorter and smaller.
